name: Svg.Plot
comment:
_Disclaimer:_ If you're looking for a plotting library, then please
use [elm-plot](https://github.com/terezka/elm-plot) instead, as this library is not
made to be user friendly. If you feel like you're missing something in elm-plot,
you're welcome to open an issue in the repo and I'll see what I can do
to accommodate your needs!

---

This module contains higher-level SVG plotting elements.


# Series

## Dots
@docs Dot, dot, clear, customDot

## Interpolation
@docs scatter, linear, monotone

## Note on usage
These elements render a line series if no `fill` attribute is added!

    areaSeries : Svg msg
    areaSeries =
      monotone plane [ fill "pink" ] dots

    lineSeries : Svg msg
    lineSeries =
      monotone plane [] dots

# Bars
@docs Bar

# Groups
@docs Groups, grouped

## Histograms
@docs Histogram, histogram

# Straight lines
@docs line, fullHorizontal, fullVertical, horizontal, vertical

## Ticks
ProTip: Passing a negative value as the height/width of a tick renders it
mirrored on the other side of the axis!

@docs xTick, xTicks, yTick, yTicks

aliases.name: Dot
aliases.type: { view : Maybe.Maybe (Float -> Float -> Svg.Svg msg) , x : Float , y : Float }

aliases.name: Histogram
aliases.comment:
The bars are the class frequencies and the interval is the class interval's
upper limit minus lower limit. Right now, you can only have equal class intervals,
but I might add unequal support later!

[What is going on with all these words?](http://onlinestatbook.com/2/graphing_distributions/histograms.html)
aliases.type: { bars : List (Svg.Plot.Bar msg) , interval : Float , intervalBegin : Float }

values.name: clear
values.comment: A dot without visual representation.

values.name: customDot
values.comment: An dot with a view where you control how it's positioned.
values.type: (Float -> Float -> Svg.Svg msg) -> Float -> Float -> Svg.Plot.Dot msg

values.name: dot
values.comment: An dot with a view which is wrapped in a `g` element and positioned with a transform.
values.type: Svg.Svg msg -> Float -> Float -> Svg.Plot.Dot msg

values.name: fullHorizontal
values.comment:
Renders a horizontal line with the full length of the range.

    myXAxisOrGridLine : Svg msg
    myXAxisOrGridLine =
      fullHorizontal plane [] yPosition
values.type: Svg.Coordinates.Plane -> List (Svg.Attribute msg) -> Float -> Svg.Svg msg

values.name: fullVertical
values.comment:
Renders a vertical line with the full length of the domain.

    myYAxisOrGridLine : Svg msg
    myYAxisOrGridLine =
      fullVertical plane [] xPosition
values.type: Svg.Coordinates.Plane -> List (Svg.Attribute msg) -> Float -> Svg.Svg msg

values.name: grouped
values.comment:
You can draw a bar chart like this:

    group : List Float -> List (Bar msg)
    group =
      List.map (Bar [ stroke "pink", fill "lightpink" ])

    groups : Groups msg
    groups =
       { groups = List.map group [ [ 2, 3, 1 ], [ 5, 1, 4 ], [ 1, 5, 3 ] ]
       , width = 0.8
       }

    main : Svg msg
    main =
      svg
        [ width (toString plane.x.length)
        , height (toString plane.y.length)
        ]
        [ grouped plane groups ]

Note on `width`: The width takes catersian units, however, should you have
a width in SVG units, you can use `Svg.Coordinates.scaleCartesian` to
translate it into cartesian units.

values.name: histogram
values.comment:
frequencies : List Float
    frequencies =
      [ 1, 2, 3, 6, 8, 9, 6, 4, 2, 1 ]

    testScores : Histogram msg
    testScores =
      { bars = List.map (Bar [ stroke blueStroke, fill blueFill ]) frequencies
      , interval = 1
      }

    main : Svg msg
    main =
      svg
        [ width (toString plane.x.length)
        , height (toString plane.y.length)
        ]
        [ histogram plane testScores ]

values.name: horizontal
values.comment:
Renders a horizontal line.

    myLine : Svg msg
    myLine =
      horizontal plane [ stroke "pink" ] y x0 x1
values.type: Svg.Coordinates.Plane -> List (Svg.Attribute msg) -> Float -> Float -> Float -> Svg.Svg msg

values.name: line
values.comment:
Renders a line.

    myLine : Svg msg
    myLine =
      horizontal plane [ stroke "pink" ] x0 y0 x1 y1
values.type: Svg.Coordinates.Plane -> List (Svg.Attribute msg) -> Float -> Float -> Float -> Float -> Svg.Svg msg

values.name: linear
values.comment: Series with linear interpolation.
values.type: Svg.Coordinates.Plane -> List (Svg.Attribute msg) -> List (Svg.Plot.Dot msg) -> Svg.Svg msg

values.name: monotone
values.comment: Series with monotone interpolation.
values.type: Svg.Coordinates.Plane -> List (Svg.Attribute msg) -> List (Svg.Plot.Dot msg) -> Svg.Svg msg

values.name: scatter
values.comment: Series with no interpolation.

values.name: vertical
values.comment:
Renders a vertical line.

    myLine : Svg msg
    myLine =
      vertical plane [ stroke "pink" ] x y0 y1
values.type: Svg.Coordinates.Plane -> List (Svg.Attribute msg) -> Float -> Float -> Float -> Svg.Svg msg

values.name: xTick
values.comment: Renders a single tick for the horizontal axis.
values.type: Svg.Coordinates.Plane -> Int -> List (Svg.Attribute msg) -> Float -> Float -> Svg.Svg msg

values.name: xTicks
values.comment:
Renders ticks for the horizontal axis.

    horizontalTicks : Svg msg
    horizontalTicks =
      xTicks plane height [ stroke "pink" ] axisYCoordinate tickPositions
values.type: Svg.Coordinates.Plane -> Int -> List (Svg.Attribute msg) -> Float -> List Float -> Svg.Svg msg

values.name: yTick
values.comment: Renders a single tick for the vertical axis.
values.type: Svg.Coordinates.Plane -> Int -> List (Svg.Attribute msg) -> Float -> Float -> Svg.Svg msg

values.name: yTicks
values.comment:
Renders ticks for the vertical axis.

    verticalTicks : Svg msg
    verticalTicks =
      yTicks plane width [ stroke "pink" ] axisXCoordinate tickPositions
values.type: Svg.Coordinates.Plane -> Int -> List (Svg.Attribute msg) -> Float -> List Float -> Svg.Svg msg

name: Svg.Coordinates
comment:
_Disclaimer:_ If you're looking for a plotting library, then please
use [elm-plot](https://github.com/terezka/elm-plot) instead, as this library is not
made to be user friendly. If you feel like you're missing something in elm-plot,
you're welcome to open an issue in the repo and I'll see what I can do
to accommodate your needs!

---

This module contains helpers for cartesian/SVG coordinate translation.

# Plane
@docs Plane, Axis

# Plane from data

You may want to produce a plane which fits all your data. For that you need
to find the minimum and maximum values withing your data in order to calculate
the domain and range.

@docs minimum, maximum

    planeFromPoints : List Point -> Plane
    planeFromPoints points =
      { x =
        { marginLower = 10
        , marginUpper = 10
        , length = 300
        , min = minimum .x points
        , max = maximum .x points
        }
      , y =
        { marginLower = 10
        , marginUpper = 10
        , length = 300
        , min = minimum .y points
        , max = maximum .y points
        }
      }

# Cartesian to SVG
@docs toSVGX, toSVGY, scaleSVG

# SVG to cartesian
@docs toCartesianX, toCartesianY, scaleCartesian

# Helpers
@docs Point, place, placeWithOffset

aliases.name: Axis
aliases.comment:
The axis of the plane.

  - The margin properties are the upper and lower margins for the axis. So for example,
    if you want to add margin on top of the plot, increase the marginUpper of
    the y-`Axis`.
  - The length is the length of your SVG axis. (`plane.x.length` is the width,
    `plane.y.length` is the height)
  - The `min` and `max` values is the reach of your plane. (Domain for the y-axis, range
    for the x-axis)
aliases.type: { marginLower : Float , marginUpper : Float , length : Float , min : Float , max : Float }

aliases.name: Point
aliases.comment: Representation of a point in your plane.

values.name: maximum
values.comment: Helper to extract the maximum value amongst your coordinates.

values.name: minimum
values.comment: Helper to extract the minimum value amongst your coordinates.

values.name: place
values.comment:
A `transform translate(x, y)` SVG attribute. Beware that using this and
  and another transform attribute on the same node, will overwrite the first.
  If that's the case, just make one yourself:

    myTransformAttribute : Svg.Attribute msg
    myTransformAttribute =
      transform <|
        "translate("
        ++ toString (toSVGX plane x) ++ ","
        ++ toString (toSVGY plane y) ++ ") "
        ++ "rotateX(" ++ whatever ++ ")"

values.name: placeWithOffset
values.comment: Place at coordinate, but you may add a SVG offset. See `place` above for important notes.
values.type: Svg.Coordinates.Plane -> Svg.Coordinates.Point -> Float -> Float -> Svg.Attribute msg

values.name: scaleCartesian
values.comment:
For scaling a SVG value to a cartesian value. Note that this will _not_
  return a coordinate on the plane, but the scaled value.

values.name: scaleSVG
values.comment:
For scaling a cartesian value to a SVG value. Note that this will _not_
  return a coordinate on the plane, but the scaled value.

values.name: toCartesianX
values.comment: Translate a cartesian x-coordinate to its SVG x-coordinate.

values.name: toCartesianY
values.comment: Translate a cartesian y-coordinate to its SVG y-coordinate.

values.name: toSVGX
values.comment: Translate a SVG x-coordinate to its cartesian x-coordinate.

values.name: toSVGY
values.comment: Translate a SVG y-coordinate to its cartesian y-coordinate.

name: Svg.Tiles
comment:
_Disclaimer:_ If you're looking for a plotting library, then please
use [elm-plot](https://github.com/terezka/elm-plot) instead, as this library is not
made to be user friendly. If you feel like you're missing something in elm-plot,
you're welcome to open an issue in the repo and I'll see what I can do
to accommodate your needs!

---

View for creating tiled maps like heatmaps or choropleths. Note that this return a SVG element not yet wrapped
in the `svg` tag.

# Composing
@docs Map, Tile, view

# Helpers
@docs tileWidth, tileHeight, tileXCoord, tileYCoord, proportion

aliases.name: Map
aliases.comment: (You can use the helpers for calculating most of these properties. You're welcome.)
aliases.type: { tiles : List (Svg.Tiles.Tile msg) , tilesPerRow : Int , tileWidth : Float , tileHeight : Float }

aliases.name: Tile
aliases.type: { content : Maybe.Maybe (Svg.Svg msg) , attributes : List (Svg.Attribute msg) , index : Int }

values.name: proportion
values.comment: For heatmaps. It calculates a value's value relative to all values.

values.name: tileHeight
values.comment:
Pass the __height__ of your map, the __amount of
 tiles in a row__, and the __total number of tiles__,
 and it gives you back the height of a single tile.

values.name: tileWidth
values.comment:
Pass the __width__ of your map, and the __amount of
 tiles in a row__, and it gives you back the width of
 a single tile.

values.name: tileXCoord
values.comment:
Pass the __tile width__, the __amount of tiles in a row__, and
 the __tile's index__ and it'll get you it's x-coordinate.

values.name: tileYCoord
values.comment:
Pass the __tile height__, the __amount of tiles in a row__ and
 the __tile's index__ and it'll get you it's y-coordinate.

values.name: view
values.comment: View a map!
